review.title: ODE - Augmented Training Improves Anomaly Detection in Sensor Data from Machines
review.abstract: Machines of all kinds from vehicles to industrial equipment are increasingly instrumented with hundreds of sensors. Using such data to detect anomalous behaviour is critical for safety and efficient maintenance. However, anomalies occur rarely and with great variety in such systems, so there is often insufficient anomalous data to build reliable detectors. A standard approach to mitigate this problem is to use one class methods relying only on data from normal behaviour. Unfortunately, even these approaches are more likely to fail in the scenario of a dynamical system with manual control input(s). Normal behaviour in response to novel control input(s) might look very different to the learned detector which may be incorrectly detected as anomalous. In this paper, we address this issue by modelling time-series via Ordinary Differential Equations (ODE) and utilising such an ODE model to simulate the behaviour of dynamical systems under varying control inputs. The available data is then augmented with data generated from the ODE, and the anomaly detector is retrained on this augmented dataset. Experiments demonstrate that ODE-augmented training data allows better coverage of possible control input(s) and results in learning more accurate distinctions between normal and anomalous behaviour in time-series.

sections.heading: 2 Proposed Approach
sections.text: Consider a multivariate time series X = {x (1), x (2),..., x (n)}, in which each point x (t) хRm in the time series is a m-dimensional vector of variables / sensors. Time series data resulting from a controlled dynamic system can normally be divided into two groups of variables: Xc is a specified "control variable" such as the position of the accelerator (APP) and Xd, the "dependent" variables such as coolant temperature (CT), torque, etc. In our application, we observe that the behavior of control variables was often relatively simple (as shown in the upper part of Fig.1), which allows us to model them using statistical distributions and generate synthetic data by scanning these distributions. We learn an ODE model for the dependent variables Xd (expressed as a function of Xc and Xd), from which we can use data to manually generate the Xsynchronized Xd series, Xchron generating the latter one.

The task of learning an ODE model can be divided into two subtasks: 1) estimation of the structure f (Pw (t), Xd (t), Xc (t)))), i.e., the type of interaction between dependent and control variables, and 2) estimation of the parameters Pw (t). sections.heading: 2.2 Using ODE to Generate Data
sections.text: As mentioned in Section 2.1, the behavior of the control variables (Xc = {APP}) is often relatively simple, e.g. the APP operates in two states: "high" and "low," as shown in Fig. 1. We learn statistical distributions, i.e. histograms for the duration and level of each state based on available training data, and sample these distributions to generate new manual control inputs. For dependent variable (s) (Xd = {CT}), we integrate numerically the learned ODE model for new control inputs (Xc = {APP}). The ODE parameters are learned for all time series pairs (APP, CT) available in the training, and such a pair is used when generating the data for a new control input (s) (Xc = {APP}).

sections.heading: 2.3 LSTM-AD: LSTM-based Anomaly Detection
sections.text: We learn a stacked / deep LSTM prediction model, in which x (t) is used to predict {x (t + 1),..., x (t + l)}, i.e. time series for the next l time steps. An error vector e (t) for the point x (t) is given by e (t) = [e (t) 1, e (t) 2,..., e (t) l], where e (t) i is the difference between enx (t) and its value, as at the time t − i. The probability that a point x (t) is normal is derived from the probability value of the corresponding error vector e (t), which is calculated from a learned Gaussian probability function over the set of error vectors from the normal data. sections.heading: 3 Experiments and Results
sections.text: We evaluate the performance of the proposed approach based on sensor data coming from a real vehicle-engine application. Two sensors in this dataset are APP and CT, the former being a manual control sensor and the latter a dependent sensor. We inject various types of anomalies in the time series recorded for normal CT operation to obtain data for abnormal behavior [3]. The following types of anomalies have been inserted: 1) sudden occurrence of a zero for a short time, 2) values that are higher / lower than the normal observed range, 3) dependent sensor CT that deviates from the expected behavior, i.e., CT behaves as if the control sensor is low when it was actually high, 4) noise in a randomly selected portion of the time series, and 5) gradual increase in the values of the CT sensor beyond the maximum observed value during normal behavior.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: Insufficient data can pose a challenge to the formation of machine learning algorithms to detect anomalies, especially for deep models. In this paper, we use ODE models from domain knowledge to extend time series data from dynamic systems. Extended time series data has proven useful to learn normal behavior more robustly. We argue that the benefits of ODE-enhanced data are based on the fact that they contain sufficient data for the normal behavior of a dynamic system with a larger collection of variations in manual control inputs. In the future, it will be interesting to explore the possibility of a purely data-driven ODE approach [12, 13].
